title.rendered: What are ICOs and how are they different from NFTs?

content.rendered:
Discover the meaning of ICOs, the new technology of the business world

As we saw in our previous article, NFTs are Non-Fungible Tokens (Non Fungible Tokens or NFT’s), a new class of digital assets that are stored and managed within a block chain. We will now see the difference between NFTs and ICOs, let’s start!

What are ICOs?

ICO is an acronym that stands for Initial Coin Offering, that is, initial currency supply. The ICO has to do with the financing of a business project.

In the case of an ICO, what is intended to be financed is the birth of a new cryptocurrency, in the style of Bitcoin or Ethereum.

All the process that has a cost and a form of finance the project it is an ICO. The developers carry out pre-mining behind closed doors and offer the new virtual currency in exchange for other currencies that are already in circulation, such as Bitcoin, and that are also exchangeable for real money in circulation. therefore one ICO is to offer initial investors the new coins in exchange for money.

Differences between NFTs and ICOs

  1. NFTs are accessible on non-ETH chains

Back then, when the smart contract was the most popular, ICOs were carried out through ETH (Ethereum). Nowadays, although ETH is still the main option to create NFTs, there are other NFT platforms that use Binance Smart Chain, Polygon, Solano, among other. While the main benefit is increased scalability, the spread of NFT applications across multiple cryptocurrencies would also expand concentration risk.

  1. Venture building VS Community building

Today, NFT it is not so much about financing a project, but rather about a fun collectible social activity This is also why leading NFT projects and NFT artists tend to be surrounded by strong communities.

  1. Investing in cryptocurrencies vs. cryptocurrency-based assets

The ICOs are used to create new cryptocurrency projects. On the other hand, NFTs do not promise new benefits or great improvements. Instead, you would be buying an asset based on cryptography which is most often a collectible and sometimes a utility token, for example a community.

Given these fundamental differences, the mindset that drives people to buy ICO’s in comparison with NFT’s it can be very different.
